summary: Manolo Ray was a Cuban exile leader, specifically of the People's Revolutionary Movement (Movimiento Revolucionario del Pueblo - MRP). The documents indicate his involvement in anti-Castro activities, particularly between 1960 and 1963. He opposed a U.S. invasion of Cuba, advocating instead for internal resistance supported by a broad base within Cuba. He sought funds and trained exiles to support this internal resistance. The documents also mention reviews of files related to anti-Castro activities involving Ray in the 1970s. His statements and activities were monitored by U.S. intelligence agencies, as evidenced by telegrams and classified messages relaying his views and movements. There is also a mention of a meeting regarding "Natolo Ray's" training efforts in Costa Rica, which may be a misspelling or related individual.
significance: While the documents detail Manolo Ray's anti-Castro activities and opposition to a U.S. invasion of Cuba, they do not directly link him to the JFK assassination. His significance lies in his role as a prominent figure within the Cuban exile community and his advocacy for internal resistance against Castro, which was a point of discussion and consideration within U.S. policy circles regarding Cuba.
